citations.desc: Primary enclosures used to transport live animals.
citations.narrative:
The licensee transported two Red foxes (tag number 9569-9570) for consignment at the Mid-Ohio Alternative Animal &
Bird Sale held the weekend of March 23-25, 2023. The transport enclosure used for the animal was a large section of wire
mesh in a dome shape with no openings or doors to allow easy access in case of an emergency. The licensee used one
square section of wire mesh for the front and back of the enclosure and secured the wire mesh with small metal clamps.
The only way to remove the animal would require the use of a tool to cut wire itself or cut the clamps off. Failure to have
openings that are accessible and allow removal of live animals in times of emergencies can result in delays to providing
care during an emergency. Correct by ensuring that all primary transport enclosures for subpart F animals have contain
openings that are easily accessible for emergency removal of live animals, for their safety and wellbeing. Correct by 7
June 2023 and prior to any future transportation of animals.

citations.desc: Primary enclosures used to transport live animals.
citations.narrative:
The licensee transported one red fox for consignment to the Mid-Ohio Alternative Animal & Bird Sale held the weekend of
March 23-25, 2023. The primary enclosure housing these foxes (tag number 9569-9570) was not marked with the words
“Live Animal” or “Wild Animal” and did not have arrows indicating the correct upright position of the cage. Auction staff
confirmed that animals are consigned with their transport enclosures and that this enclosure was the same that the
licensee transported the animal in for consignment. Failure to clearly mark transport enclosures can result in inappropriate
handling of the cages as its contents and position may be unclear to the staff. Correct by ensuring that all primary
enclosures used to transport live animals are marked with the words “Live Animal” or “Wild Animal” in letters at least 1
inch in height and with arrows or other markings to indicate the correct upright position of the container. Correct by 7
June 2023 and prior to any future transportation of animals.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee via phone.
Additional Inspectors:
Jonathan Tomkovitch, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER
William Janecke, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER
Mark Sanderbeck, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

narrative:
3.137(a)(3) 
   
Primary enclosures used to transport live animals. 
The licensee transported two Red foxes (tag number 9569-9570) for consignment at the Mid-Ohio Alternative Animal & 
Bird Sale held the weekend of March 23-25, 2023. The transport enclosure used for the animal was a large section of wire 
mesh in a dome shape with no openings or doors to allow easy access in case of an emergency. The licensee used one 
square section of wire mesh for the front and back of the enclosure and secured the wire mesh with small metal clamps. 
The only way to remove the animal would require the use of a tool to cut wire itself or cut the clamps off.  Failure to have 
openings that are accessible and allow removal of live animals in times of emergencies can result in delays to providing 
care during an emergency.  Correct by ensuring that all primary transport enclosures for subpart F animals have contain 
openings that are easily accessible for emergency removal of live animals, for their safety and wellbeing. Correct by 7 
June 2023 and prior to any future transportation of animals. 
3.137(e) 
   
Primary enclosures used to transport live animals. 
The licensee transported one red fox for consignment to the Mid-Ohio Alternative Animal & Bird Sale held the weekend of 
March 23-25, 2023.  The primary enclosure housing these foxes (tag number 9569-9570) was not marked with the words 
“Live Animal” or “Wild Animal” and did not have arrows indicating the correct upright position of the cage.  Auction staff 
confirmed that animals are consigned with their transport enclosures and that this enclosure was the same that the

licensee transported the animal in for consignment. Failure to clearly mark transport enclosures can result in inappropriate 
handling of the cages as its contents and position may be unclear to the staff. Correct by ensuring that all primary 
enclosures used to transport live animals are marked with the words “Live Animal” or “Wild Animal” in letters at least 1 
inch in height and with arrows or other markings to indicate the correct upright position of the container.  Correct by 7 
June 2023 and prior to any future transportation of animals. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with  the licensee via phone. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Jonathan Tomkovitch, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER 
William Janecke, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER 
Mark Sanderbeck, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n
